title.narrative: Technical Assistance to Strengthen Legislation, Prosecution Efforts, and Protection Measures to Combat Trafficking in Persons in Papua New Guinea

description.narrative: IOM is supporting the establishment and institutionalization of a national referral mechanism in Papua New Guinea by providing populations at risk of being trafficked with access to information and justice. IOM is (1) developing and piloting in the National Capital District a multi-disciplinary, multi-sectoral victim-centered protection and referral mechanism for victims of trafficking; and (2) building the capacity and increasing involvement of the National Human Trafficking Committee on policy formation and monitoring as a way of raising the priority of combating human trafficking within the Government of Papua New Guinea.

person-name.narrative: Jenee Sharon; Wes Aviles; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Combating Trafficking in Human Beings in Papua New Guinea Phase II

description.narrative: Between September 30, 2012 and September 30, 2014, IOM PNG will build upon achievements obtained, and scale up activities implemented, under the current project by further strengthening the capacity of the PNG government to prosecute traffickers and protect victims of trafficking (VoTs). The project will be comprised of four components: 1.) Policy, 2.) Prevention, 3.) Prosecution, 4.) Protection. This second phase of the project will expand the present geographic scope, maintaining operation in the current border provinces of West Sepik, Western, National Capital District (NCD) and the Autonomous Region of Bougainville (ARB), and scaling up the same set of activities under Phase I in the new project provinces of Eastern Highlands, Morobe and Madang, located across the coastal and highlands region of PNG's mainland. National strategies for the implementation of the new trafficking in persons (TIP) legislation to be passed by Parliament will be supported by technical assistance provided by IOM at the national level, under component 1. An increase in the reporting of trafficking cases will be supported through wider awareness raising utilizing multi-media and community-level awareness sessions, and monitored through the continuation of a dedicated toll-free trafficking telephone hotline under component 2. An increase in investigation of trafficking cases and the number of VofT referred to direct assistance will be supported through delivery of joint law enforcement training, under component 3. Referral systems between law enforcement, border control authorities, and service providers in accordance with the new TIP law will be established with support by IOM under component 4.

person-name.narrative: Jenee Sharon; Wes Aviles; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Preservation of Malagan Carving Traditions in New Ireland

description.narrative: Traditional malagancarved and decorated masks and other objectsare central to cultural life in New Ireland province, yet few master malagan carvers survive. This project includes the transfer of knowledge and skills associated with malagan carving and ceremonies from master carvers to local apprentices.

title.narrative: PNG Women's Chamber of Commerce

description.narrative: Support the National Endowment for Democracys Center for International Private Enterprise (NED/CIPE) development program for the Papua New Guinea Womens Chamber of Commerce. The goals is to poormote the development, sustainability and advocacy skills of the nascent Papua New Guinea Womens Chamber of Commerce. Activities will be aimed at accomplishing APEC's cross-cutting goals of empowering women entrepreneurs; strengthening womens voices in public policymaking through independent, self-sustaining and politically influential business associations; and strengthening women small business owners' access to international networks and markets. .
